meanings.definition: To make oneself look neat and tidy
meanings.sent1: She primmed her hair before going out.
meanings.sent2: He always primmed his uniform before inspection.
meanings.sent3: The cat primmed its fur after a nap, looking quite dapper.
meanings.sent4: The garden was primmed with colorful flowers, creating a neat display.
meanings.sent5: The students primmed their desks for the upcoming exam, organizing everything meticulously.

meanings.definition: To purse one's lips in a disapproving manner
meanings.sent1: She primmed her lips when she saw the messy room.
meanings.sent2: He primmed in disapproval at the rude comment.
meanings.sent3: The toddler primmed at the sight of vegetables on his plate.
meanings.sent4: The judge primmed as the defendant gave a flimsy excuse.
meanings.sent5: The teacher primmed at the students' lack of preparation for the test.
